================================================================================
CONFIDENCE CALIBRATION ANALYSIS
Dataset: OSCAR
================================================================================

PREDICTION OUTCOMES
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TP: 1832 ( 44.6%)
TN: 1896 ( 46.2%)
FP:  156 (  3.8%)
FN:  220 (  5.4%)
Total: 4104

CALIBRATION ANALYSIS
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Correct predictions (n=3728):
  Mean confidence:  0.9831 (SD: 0.0837)
  Median:           0.9999

Incorrect predictions (n=376):
  Mean confidence:  0.8816 (SD: 0.2004)
  Median:           0.9867

Statistical comparison (Correct vs Incorrect):
  Test: Mann-Whitney U (one-sided: correct > incorrect)
  U statistic: 1180689.50
  P-value: 9.95e-107
  Effect size (rank-biserial r): +0.685
  Interpretation: large
  Significant at α=0.001: ✓ Yes

TRUE POSITIVES vs FALSE POSITIVES (Critical for Label Noise)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
True Positives (n=1832):
  Mean:  0.9710 (SD: 0.1105)

False Positives (n=156):
  Mean:  0.9308 (SD: 0.1698)

Statistical comparison (TP vs FP):
  Test: Mann-Whitney U (one-sided: TP > FP)
  P-value: 1.37e-10
  Effect size (r): +0.304 (medium)
  Significant at α=0.001: ✓ Yes

================================================================================
SUGGESTED TEXT FOR PAPER
================================================================================

To verify that high sensitivity reflects genuine discriminative ability rather
than uniform positive bias, we analyzed GPT-4o's prediction confidence via
log-probabilities on the OSCAR. Correct predictions exhibited
significantly higher confidence (mean logprob: 0.98, SD: 0.08)
than incorrect predictions (mean: 0.88, SD: 0.20);
Mann-Whitney U test, p < 0.001, effect size r = +0.68
(large effect).

Critically, true positive predictions showed higher confidence
(mean logprob: 0.97) than false positive predictions
(mean: 0.93), with the difference
being statistically significant (Mann-Whitney U, p < 0.001,
r = +0.30, medium effect). This calibration
pattern indicates the model assigns high confidence selectively to genuine
interactions rather than indiscriminately to all positive predictions.
